awd_titl_txt: From memory flexibility to cognitive flexibility: Examining precursors to bilingual advantages during early childhood
awd_abstract_narration:
Two-thirds of the world's children are raised in homes where multiple languages are spoken. Children who learn two or more languages exhibit what appear to be lifelong cognitive advantages relative to those who learn only one language.  In particular, bilingual children show heightened cognitive flexibility, defined as the ability to adjust their behaviors in response to changes in task demands, and inhibit their attention to irrelevant information.  Cognitive flexibility is critical to educational success.  The proposed studies will examine whether advantages in memory processing during infancy can explain bilingual children's heightened cognitive flexibility later in childhood. A better understanding of how and why bilingualism enhances cognitive flexibility will allow educators to develop pedagogical strategies to capitalize on bilingualism's protective cognitive strengths. This may be especially important for bilingual children from low income families who show an achievement gap relative to their middle class, monolingual peers.

 Memory inference and memory flexibility will be tested in 1- and 2-year-old monolingual and bilingual children and these same children will be tested at 3- and 5-years on cognitive flexibility. Memory flexibility involves the ability to recognize similarities between objects based on how they function rather than how they look, which involves the ability to shift between cues. Memory interference occurs when competing cues disrupt memory encoding, and reduction of interference requires inhibition of conflicting cues.  It is predicted that longitudinal analyses will show that bilingual infants have greater memory flexibility and less memory interference than monolinguals, which will predict enhanced cognitive flexibility at both 3 and 5 years.  In addition, the PI is committed to training graduate and undergraduate students and will recruit bilingual students for their unique linguistic skills; the project is therefore likely to train minority students who are underrepresented in STEM fields.

por.por_cntn:
Bilingual exposure alters both perceptual and cognitive trajectories starting during infancy. The differences are thought to result in lifelong differences in cognitive flexibility, defined as the ability to adjust to changes in tasks demands to switch between tasks as needed. The project investigated whether there were bilingual differences in memory flexibility (remembering better in novel situations) or memory interference (ignoring irrelevant memory cues) during early children.  We followed infants from 18 months through 5 years of life. Home visits occurred at 1.5 years, 2 years, 3 years, and 5 years and we have tracked ~100 families across time. Infants grew up exposed a diverse range of linguistic experiences, from 100% one language to 50% 2 languages and in some cases were exposed to more than 2 languages and there were significant fluctuations in exposure to different languages across time particularly preschool entry. We developed new tools to investigate memory flexibility and memory interference. We found that at 1.5 and 2 years that bilingual differences in flexibility persisted and that patterns of attention between monolinguals and bilinguals also differed. That is early language exposure does shape both selective attention and memory flexibility. We also saw that monolinguals and bilinguals relied on different strategies to remember new words. This difference makes sense because bilinguals must learn that multiple words map onto the same object and therefore strategies effective for learning one language are not as effective for learning more than one language.  However, there were no differences in the ability to ignore irrelevant information or memory interference or processing of conflicting information in 1.5- and 2-year-olds. By 3 years of age memory flexibility differences decreased but were replaced by differences in cognitive flexibility.  Overall, this pattern of results shows that there are significant differences between monolinguals and bilingual infants on memory flexibility, selective attention, cognitive flexibility, and word learning across early childhood and that language exposure patterns frequently change during that timeframe. We will continue to use this dataset to examine longitudinal patterns in memory and cognitive flexibility from 1.5 to 5 years of age. For example, we will examine whether performance on memory interference tasks predicts later performance on memory flexibility or cognitive flexibility and how language exposure fluctuations are associated with this pattern of results.  These findings have important theoretical implications for our understanding of individual differences in cognitive development and practical implications for early educators working with children who have diverse language learning environments linked to both language learning strategies and cognitive flexibility.
